comment_text.mn95:1.2: Opāsāda does not appear anywhere else. We later hear of Caṅkī’s longhouse (pāsāda), a luxurious residence to the north of the town on the way to the Godswood. Perhaps, then, Opāsāda means “below the mansion”.
comment_text.mn95:1.3: A grove in which offerings were made to the gods.
comment_text.mn95:2.1: Caṅkī is regularly mentioned along with other senior brahmins Tārukkha, Pokkharasāti, Jānussoṇi, and Todeyya (DN 13:2.2, MN 98:2.2, MN 99:13.5, Snp 3.9:1.4). His name is obscure; spelled caṅgī in Sanskrit, it is perhaps related to the gatāgate caṅgimā of Mahā-subhāṣita-Saṁgraha 7235-1, where it refers to the sensual walk of a young woman; dictionaries record the sense “beautiful” for Kannada caṁgi and Sanskrit caṅgiman. | “Royal park” is rājadāya (cp. migadāya, “deer park”). | A brahmadeyya is a gift of land by a king to a brahmin, which was an outstanding feature of Indian feudalism. Similar grants are mentioned in the Dīgha Nikāya at DN 3:1.2.1, DN 5:1.4, DN 12:1.3, and DN 23:1.4.
comment_text.mn95:5.1: Also a favored siesta location for Soṇadaṇḍa (DN 5:3.1), Kūṭadanta (DN 4:3.1), and Pāyāsi (DN 23:3.1).
comment_text.mn95:5.3: The khatta (“butler”; Sanskrit kṣattṛ) was a senior member of the household staff, responsible for management of activities (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.3.1.7).
comment_text.mn95:8.4: Jātivāda is sometimes translated as “doctrine of birth”, but the context here shows this cannot be the case. It refers to the genealogical records of the family lineage.
comment_text.mn95:8.9: Brahmavarcasa (“divine lustre”) commonly describes a spiritual or ethereal beauty due to ritual (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 13.1.9, 2.3.1, 4.1.1), or simply the healthy glow from time in the sun, which if overdone leads to sunburn (eg. Taittirīya Saṁhita 2.10.2). Brahmavarṇa (“divine looks”), on the other hand, seems unknown in the Vedic tradition. | For Mahāsaṅgīti vacchasī read vaccasī (Sanskrit varcasin), “possessing lustre”.
comment_text.mn95:8.12: Notice that the royal endowment was not just for a luxury residence, it was the site of a major international college. Kings invested in education.
comment_text.mn95:9.18: “Distant land” (tiroraṭṭha) is defined at Bi Pc 38:2.6 as “any land other than where one is living”.
comment_text.mn95:9.25: Refuge of Pokkharasāti and family is at DN 3:2.22.4.
comment_text.mn95:11.2: This student’s education is like that of Assalāyana (MN 93:3.1), but his character could not be more different. His name has a variety of spellings in Pali and Sanskrit, but the correct form is kāpaṭika from kapaṭa, “fraud”. Kauṭilya explains that fraudulent students (chātraḥ kāpaṭikaḥ) were spies installed by kings to test the loyalty of subjects (Arthaśāstra 1.10.11, 1.11.1–2), for which they were paid handsomely (5.3.22). Note that the Buddha calls him Bhāradvāja; this follows the convention in Pali that brahmins of that name are distinguished by epithets, often unflattering: Bhāradvāja the Farmer (Snp 1.4:1.3), Bhāradvāja the Fire-Worshiper (Snp 1.7:1.4), Bhāradvāja the Alms-Gatherer (SN 35.127:1.1), Bhāradvāja the Builder (SN 7.17:1.2), Bhāradvāja the Rude (SN 7.2:1.2), Bhāradvāja the Fiend (SN 7.3:1.2), Bhāradvāja the Bitter (SN 7.4:1.2), and so on. Thus Kāpaṭika would have been an epithet recognizing that he was the king’s spy, a practice to which Pasenadi openly admits (SN 3.11:7.1, Ud 6.2:8.1). This was the downside of building a religious institution on the king’s largess. Whether he was recognized as a spy at the time, or the epithet was applied later, is uncertain, but at some point it seems the meaning was forgotten and the epithet was taken to be his proper name.
comment_text.mn95:11.5: It is rare for the Buddha to address a lay person as “venerable” (āyasmā). It seems the form is excessively polite to soften the rebuke.
comment_text.mn95:12.1: This passage is unique to to this sutta.
comment_text.mn95:12.11: The “lineage of testament” (itihitihaparamparā); “canonical authority” (piṭakasampadā); “ancient hymnal” (porāṇaṁ mantapadaṁ): these refer to the Vedas.
comment_text.mn95:13.9: The ten names in Pali include the seven authors of the so-called “family books” of the Rig Veda (Maṇḍalas 2–8). As founders of poetic lineages, we often find works by their descendants, which are not always confined to their dedicated family book. Poems by the other three authors are mostly outside the family books. Thus the sages listed here cover most of the Rig Veda, although the Vedic tradition records many other authors as well. | Atri Bhauma (Maṇḍala 5, rather than Aṣṭaka Vaiśvāmitra of 10.104); Vamra(ka) Vaikhānasa (10.99; see 9.66); Vāmadeva Gautama (Maṇḍala 4); Viśvāmitra Gāthina (Maṇḍala 3); Jamadagni Bhārgava was a descendant of Bhṛgu (several hymns mostly in Maṇḍalas 9 and 10); Aṅgirasa is identified with Agni as the founder of a lineage of poet-singers (Maṇḍala 8); Bharadvāja Bārhaspatya (Maṇḍala 6); Vasiṣṭha Maitrāvaruṇi (Maṇḍala 7); Kaśyapa Mārīca (several hymns mostly in Maṇḍalas 9 and 10); Bhṛgu was the bringer of fire from heaven whose adoptive descendant was Gṛtsamada Bhārgava Śaunaka (Maṇḍala 2).
comment_text.mn95:13.23: The “blind following the blind” is also at MN 95:13.24 and MN 99:9.25. Maitrī Upaniṣad 7.8–9 turns it around, saying that the blind teach false doctrines aimed at destroying the Vedas, “the doctrine of not-self” (nairātmyavāda), an obvious reference to Buddhists. We also find it at Kaṭha Upaniṣad 1.2.5, Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad 1.2.8, Mahābhārata 2.38.3, and the Jain Sūyagaḍa 1.1.2.19.
comment_text.mn95:14.1: “Faith” is saddhā (see note on MN 26:15.9) | “Oral transmission” is anussava. While the idea of oral tradition was of course central to Vedism, we don’t seem to find the term until later (eg. Bhāgavata Purāṇa 5.8.29; Śrīdhara’s commentary on Bhagavad-Gītā 18.3). | See too MN 76:24.1.
comment_text.mn95:14.5: Parivitakka means “train of thought”, as when the Buddha reads Kāpaṭika’s thoughts above (MN 95:12.6). Ākāra in this context means “reason”, as at MN 47:10.2; the current sutta expands on the ideas there. | Khanti is usually better rendered “acceptance” than the common “patience”.
comment_text.mn95:14.9: Ruci means “liking, preference”, and from there takes the sense of “endorsing” an idea or belief, in which case it can be translated as “opinion”.
comment_text.mn95:14.14: This sutta introduces the important epistemological distinction between the “preservation of truth” (saccānurakkhaṇā), the “awakening to the truth” (saccānubodha), and the “attainment of the truth” (saccānuppatti).
comment_text.mn95:15.14: This is essentially the standard used in references today: one should accurately represent one’s sources.
comment_text.mn95:20.2: Here we see the meaning of the Buddhist “grounded faith” (ākāravatī saddhā, MN 47:16.1, MN 60:4.1) as opposed to “blind faith”. But faith is only the beginning of the long and demanding process described here.
comment_text.mn95:21.4: Typically this distinction refers to the stream-enterer and the arahant.
comment_text.mn95:23.3: Tulanā is literally “weighing”, here in the applied sense of “evaluating”.
comment_text.mn95:24.3: Here, “zeal” (ussāha) is making an effort to understand the teachings, while “striving” (padhāna) is making an effort in meditation.
comment_text.mn95:35.2: That Kāpaṭika should sincerely go forth does not conflict with him being a spy; it is a conversion story. In authoritarian countries today, spies are regularly placed in monasteries for the same reason. There are stories of how, after being placed for many years and seeing not a hotbed of sedition but a place for wisdom and goodness, such spies feel shame and genuinely convert to Buddhism.

root_text.mn95:10.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn95:11.1: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā vuddhehi vuddhehi brāhmaṇehi saddhiṁ kiñci kiñci kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā nisinno hoti.
root_text.mn95:11.2: Tena kho pana samayena kāpaṭiko nāma māṇavo daharo vuttasiro soḷasavassuddesiko jātiyā, tiṇṇaṁ vedānaṁ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṁ sākkharappabhedānaṁ itihāsapañcamānaṁ, padako, veyyākaraṇo, lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo tassaṁ parisāyaṁ nisinno hoti.
root_text.mn95:11.3: So vuddhānaṁ vuddhānaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ bhagavatā saddhiṁ mantayamānānaṁ antarantarā kathaṁ opāteti.
root_text.mn95:11.4: Atha kho bhagavā kāpaṭikaṁ māṇavaṁ apasādeti:
root_text.mn95:11.5: “māyasmā bhāradvājo vuddhānaṁ vuddhānaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ mantayamānānaṁ antarantarā kathaṁ opātetu.
root_text.mn95:11.7: Evaṁ vutte, caṅkī brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn95:11.9: kulaputto ca kāpaṭiko māṇavo, bahussuto ca kāpaṭiko māṇavo, paṇḍito ca kāpaṭiko māṇavo, kalyāṇavākkaraṇo ca kāpaṭiko māṇavo, pahoti ca kāpaṭiko māṇavo bhotā gotamena saddhiṁ asmiṁ vacane paṭimantetun”ti.
root_text.mn95:12.2: “addhā kho kāpaṭikassa māṇavassa tevijjake pāvacane kathā bhavissati.
root_text.mn95:12.5: “yadā me samaṇo gotamo cakkhuṁ upasaṁharissati, athāhaṁ samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ pañhaṁ pucchissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn95:12.6: Atha kho bhagavā kāpaṭikassa māṇavassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya yena kāpaṭiko māṇavo tena cakkhūni upasaṁhāsi.
root_text.mn95:12.10: Atha kho kāpaṭiko māṇavo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn95:12.11: “yadidaṁ, bho gotama, brāhmaṇānaṁ porāṇaṁ mantapadaṁ itihitihaparamparāya piṭakasampadāya, tattha ca brāhmaṇā ekaṁsena niṭṭhaṁ gacchanti:
root_text.mn95:13.1: “Kiṁ pana, bhāradvāja, atthi koci brāhmaṇānaṁ ekabrāhmaṇopi yo evamāha:
root_text.mn95:13.5: “Kiṁ pana, bhāradvāja, atthi koci brāhmaṇānaṁ ekācariyopi, ekācariyapācariyopi, yāva sattamā ācariyamahayugāpi, yo evamāha:
root_text.mn95:13.9: “Kiṁ pana, bhāradvāja, yepi te brāhmaṇānaṁ pubbakā isayo mantānaṁ kattāro mantānaṁ pavattāro yesamidaṁ etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇaṁ mantapadaṁ gītaṁ pavuttaṁ samihitaṁ tadanugāyanti tadanubhāsanti bhāsitamanubhāsanti vācitamanuvācenti seyyathidaṁ—aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo vessāmitto yamataggi aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu,
root_text.mn95:13.14: “Iti kira, bhāradvāja, natthi koci brāhmaṇānaṁ ekabrāhmaṇopi yo evamāha:
root_text.mn95:13.17: natthi koci brāhmaṇānaṁ ekācariyopi ekācariyapācariyopi, yāva sattamā ācariyamahayugāpi, yo evamāha:
root_text.mn95:13.20: yepi te brāhmaṇānaṁ pubbakā isayo mantānaṁ kattāro mantānaṁ pavattāro yesamidaṁ etarahi brāhmaṇā porāṇaṁ mantapadaṁ gītaṁ pavuttaṁ samihitaṁ tadanugāyanti tadanubhāsanti bhāsitamanubhāsanti vācitamanuvācenti seyyathidaṁ—aṭṭhako vāmako vāmadevo vessāmitto yamataggi aṅgīraso bhāradvājo vāseṭṭho kassapo bhagu, tepi na evamāhaṁsu:
root_text.mn95:13.23: Seyyathāpi, bhāradvāja, andhaveṇi paramparāsaṁsattā purimopi na passati majjhimopi na passati pacchimopi na passati;
root_text.mn95:13.24: evameva kho, bhāradvāja, andhaveṇūpamaṁ maññe brāhmaṇānaṁ bhāsitaṁ sampajjati—purimopi na passati majjhimopi na passati pacchimopi na passati.
root_text.mn95:13.26: nanu evaṁ sante brāhmaṇānaṁ amūlikā saddhā sampajjatī”ti?
root_text.mn95:14.1: “Na khvettha, bho gotama, brāhmaṇā saddhāyeva payirupāsanti, anussavāpettha brāhmaṇā payirupāsantī”ti.
root_text.mn95:14.2: “Pubbeva kho tvaṁ, bhāradvāja, saddhaṁ agamāsi, anussavaṁ idāni vadesi.
root_text.mn95:14.3: Pañca kho ime, bhāradvāja, dhammā diṭṭheva dhamme dvedhā vipākā.
root_text.mn95:14.6: ime kho, bhāradvāja, pañca dhammā diṭṭheva dhamme dvedhā vipākā.
root_text.mn95:14.7: Api ca, bhāradvāja, susaddahitaṁyeva hoti, tañca hoti rittaṁ tucchaṁ musā;
root_text.mn95:14.8: no cepi susaddahitaṁ hoti, tañca hoti bhūtaṁ tacchaṁ anaññathā.
root_text.mn95:14.12: sunijjhāyitaṁyeva hoti, tañca hoti rittaṁ tucchaṁ musā;
root_text.mn95:14.13: no cepi sunijjhāyitaṁ hoti, tañca hoti bhūtaṁ tacchaṁ anaññathā.
root_text.mn95:14.14: Saccamanurakkhatā, bhāradvāja, viññunā purisena nālamettha ekaṁsena niṭṭhaṁ gantuṁ:
root_text.mn95:15.1: “Kittāvatā pana, bho gotama, saccānurakkhaṇā hoti, kittāvatā saccamanurakkhati?
root_text.mn95:15.5: iti vadaṁ saccamanurakkhati, na tveva tāva ekaṁsena niṭṭhaṁ gacchati:
root_text.mn95:15.12: iti vadaṁ saccamanurakkhati, na tveva tāva ekaṁsena niṭṭhaṁ gacchati:
root_text.mn95:15.14: Ettāvatā kho, bhāradvāja, saccānurakkhaṇā hoti, ettāvatā saccamanurakkhati, ettāvatā ca mayaṁ saccānurakkhaṇaṁ paññapema;
root_text.mn95:16.1: “Ettāvatā, bho gotama, saccānurakkhaṇā hoti, ettāvatā saccamanurakkhati, ettāvatā ca mayaṁ saccānurakkhaṇaṁ pekkhāma.
root_text.mn95:16.2: Kittāvatā pana, bho gotama, saccānubodho hoti, kittāvatā saccamanubujjhati?
root_text.mn95:17.1: “Idha, bhāradvāja, bhikkhu aññataraṁ gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā upanissāya viharati.
root_text.mn95:17.2: Tamenaṁ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā upasaṅkamitvā tīsu dhammesu samannesati—
root_text.mn95:17.3: lobhanīyesu dhammesu, dosanīyesu dhammesu, mohanīyesu dhammesu.
root_text.mn95:17.4: Atthi nu kho imassāyasmato tathārūpā lobhanīyā dhammā yathārūpehi lobhanīyehi dhammehi pariyādinnacitto ajānaṁ vā vadeyya—
root_text.mn95:17.6: passāmīti, paraṁ vā tadatthāya samādapeyya yaṁ paresaṁ assa dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyāti?
root_text.mn95:17.8: ‘natthi kho imassāyasmato tathārūpā lobhanīyā dhammā yathārūpehi lobhanīyehi dhammehi pariyādinnacitto ajānaṁ vā vadeyya—
root_text.mn95:17.10: passāmīti, paraṁ vā tadatthāya samādapeyya yaṁ paresaṁ assa dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya.
root_text.mn95:17.11: Tathārūpo kho panimassāyasmato kāyasamācāro tathārūpo vacīsamācāro yathā taṁ aluddhassa.
root_text.mn95:17.12: Yaṁ kho pana ayamāyasmā dhammaṁ deseti, gambhīro so dhammo duddaso duranubodho santo paṇīto atakkāvacaro nipuṇo paṇḍitavedanīyo;
root_text.mn95:18.1: Yato naṁ samannesamāno visuddhaṁ lobhanīyehi dhammehi samanupassati tato naṁ uttari samannesati dosanīyesu dhammesu.
root_text.mn95:18.2: Atthi nu kho imassāyasmato tathārūpā dosanīyā dhammā yathārūpehi dosanīyehi dhammehi pariyādinnacitto ajānaṁ vā vadeyya—
root_text.mn95:18.4: passāmīti, paraṁ vā tadatthāya samādapeyya yaṁ paresaṁ assa dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyāti?
root_text.mn95:18.6: ‘natthi kho imassāyasmato tathārūpā dosanīyā dhammā yathārūpehi dosanīyehi dhammehi pariyādinnacitto ajānaṁ vā vadeyya—
root_text.mn95:18.8: passāmīti, paraṁ vā tadatthāya samādapeyya yaṁ paresaṁ assa dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāya.
root_text.mn95:18.9: Tathārūpo kho panimassāyasmato kāyasamācāro tathārūpo vacīsamācāro yathā taṁ aduṭṭhassa.

root_text.mn95:20.1: Yato naṁ samannesamāno visuddhaṁ mohanīyehi dhammehi samanupassati;

root_text.mn95:20.3: Ettāvatā kho, bhāradvāja, saccānubodho hoti, ettāvatā saccamanubujjhati, ettāvatā ca mayaṁ saccānubodhaṁ paññapema;
root_text.mn95:21.1: “Ettāvatā, bho gotama, saccānubodho hoti, ettāvatā saccamanubujjhati, ettāvatā ca mayaṁ saccānubodhaṁ pekkhāma.
root_text.mn95:21.2: Kittāvatā pana, bho gotama, saccānuppatti hoti, kittāvatā saccamanupāpuṇāti?
root_text.mn95:21.4: “Tesaṁyeva, bhāradvāja, dhammānaṁ āsevanā bhāvanā bahulīkammaṁ saccānuppatti hoti.
root_text.mn95:21.5: Ettāvatā kho, bhāradvāja, saccānuppatti hoti, ettāvatā saccamanupāpuṇāti, ettāvatā ca mayaṁ saccānuppattiṁ paññapemā”ti.
root_text.mn95:22.1: “Ettāvatā, bho gotama, saccānuppatti hoti, ettāvatā saccamanupāpuṇāti, ettāvatā ca mayaṁ saccānuppattiṁ pekkhāma.
root_text.mn95:22.2: Saccānuppattiyā pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?
root_text.mn95:22.3: Saccānuppattiyā bahukāraṁ dhammaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ pucchāmā”ti.
root_text.mn95:22.6: Yasmā ca kho padahati tasmā saccamanupāpuṇāti.

root_text.mn95:24.2: Tulanāya bahukāraṁ dhammaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ pucchāmā”ti.
root_text.mn95:24.5: Yasmā ca kho ussahati tasmā tuleti.

root_text.mn95:25.2: Ussāhassa bahukāraṁ dhammaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ pucchāmā”ti.

root_text.mn95:26.5: Yasmā ca kho dhammā nijjhānaṁ khamanti tasmā chando jāyati.
root_text.mn95:27.1: “Dhammanijjhānakkhantiyā pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?
root_text.mn95:27.2: Dhammanijjhānakkhantiyā bahukāraṁ dhammaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ pucchāmā”ti.
root_text.mn95:27.4: No cetaṁ atthaṁ upaparikkheyya, nayidaṁ dhammā nijjhānaṁ khameyyuṁ.
root_text.mn95:27.5: Yasmā ca kho atthaṁ upaparikkhati tasmā dhammā nijjhānaṁ khamanti.
root_text.mn95:28.1: “Atthūpaparikkhāya pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?
root_text.mn95:28.2: Atthūpaparikkhāya bahukāraṁ dhammaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ pucchāmā”ti.
root_text.mn95:28.4: No cetaṁ dhammaṁ dhāreyya, nayidaṁ atthaṁ upaparikkheyya.
root_text.mn95:28.5: Yasmā ca kho dhammaṁ dhāreti tasmā atthaṁ upaparikkhati.
root_text.mn95:29.1: “Dhammadhāraṇāya pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?
root_text.mn95:29.2: Dhammadhāraṇāya bahukāraṁ dhammaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ pucchāmā”ti.
root_text.mn95:29.4: No cetaṁ dhammaṁ suṇeyya, nayidaṁ dhammaṁ dhāreyya.
root_text.mn95:29.5: Yasmā ca kho dhammaṁ suṇāti tasmā dhammaṁ dhāreti.
root_text.mn95:30.1: “Dhammassavanassa pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?
root_text.mn95:30.2: Dhammassavanassa bahukāraṁ dhammaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ pucchāmā”ti.
root_text.mn95:30.4: No cetaṁ sotaṁ odaheyya, nayidaṁ dhammaṁ suṇeyya.
root_text.mn95:30.5: Yasmā ca kho sotaṁ odahati tasmā dhammaṁ suṇāti.
root_text.mn95:31.1: “Sotāvadhānassa pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?
root_text.mn95:31.2: Sotāvadhānassa bahukāraṁ dhammaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ pucchāmā”ti.
root_text.mn95:31.4: No cetaṁ payirupāseyya, nayidaṁ sotaṁ odaheyya.
root_text.mn95:31.5: Yasmā ca kho payirupāsati tasmā sotaṁ odahati.
root_text.mn95:32.1: “Payirupāsanāya pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?
root_text.mn95:32.2: Payirupāsanāya bahukāraṁ dhammaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ pucchāmā”ti.
root_text.mn95:32.5: Yasmā ca kho upasaṅkamati tasmā payirupāsati.
root_text.mn95:33.1: “Upasaṅkamanassa pana, bho gotama, katamo dhammo bahukāro?
root_text.mn95:33.2: Upasaṅkamanassa bahukāraṁ dhammaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ pucchāmā”ti.
root_text.mn95:33.4: No cetaṁ saddhā jāyetha, nayidaṁ upasaṅkameyya.
root_text.mn95:33.5: Yasmā ca kho saddhā jāyati tasmā upasaṅkamati.
root_text.mn95:34.1: “Saccānurakkhaṇaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ apucchimha, saccānurakkhaṇaṁ bhavaṁ gotamo byākāsi;
root_text.mn95:34.2: tañca panamhākaṁ ruccati ceva khamati ca tena camha attamanā.
root_text.mn95:34.3: Saccānubodhaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ apucchimha, saccānubodhaṁ bhavaṁ gotamo byākāsi;
root_text.mn95:34.4: tañca panamhākaṁ ruccati ceva khamati ca tena camha attamanā.
root_text.mn95:34.5: Saccānuppattiṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ apucchimha, saccānuppattiṁ bhavaṁ gotamo byākāsi;
root_text.mn95:34.6: tañca panamhākaṁ ruccati ceva khamati ca tena camha attamanā.
root_text.mn95:34.7: Saccānuppattiyā bahukāraṁ dhammaṁ mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ apucchimha, saccānuppattiyā bahukāraṁ dhammaṁ bhavaṁ gotamo byākāsi;
root_text.mn95:34.8: tañca panamhākaṁ ruccati ceva khamati ca tena camha attamanā.
root_text.mn95:34.9: Yaṁyadeva ca mayaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ apucchimha taṁtadeva bhavaṁ gotamo byākāsi;
root_text.mn95:34.10: tañca panamhākaṁ ruccati ceva khamati ca tena camha attamanā.
root_text.mn95:34.11: Mayañhi, bho gotama, pubbe evaṁ jānāma:
root_text.mn95:34.12: ‘ke ca muṇḍakā samaṇakā ibbhā kaṇhā bandhupādāpaccā, ke ca dhammassa aññātāro’ti?
root_text.mn95:34.13: Ajanesi vata me bhavaṁ gotamo samaṇesu samaṇapemaṁ, samaṇesu samaṇapasādaṁ, samaṇesu samaṇagāravaṁ.
root_text.mn95:35.2: upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.

translation_text.mn95:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Opāsāda.
translation_text.mn95:1.3: He stayed in the Godswood of sal trees to the north of Opāsāda.
translation_text.mn95:2.1: Now at that time the brahmin Caṅkī was living in Opāsāda. It was a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.
translation_text.mn95:3.1: The brahmins and householders of Opāsāda heard:
translation_text.mn95:3.2: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Opāsāda together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. He is staying in the Godswood to the north.
translation_text.mn95:3.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.mn95:3.5: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.mn95:3.6: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
translation_text.mn95:3.7: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
translation_text.mn95:4.1: Then, exiting Opāsāda, they formed into companies and headed north to the Godswood.
translation_text.mn95:5.1: Now at that time the brahmin Caṅkī had retired to the upper floor of his stilt longhouse for his midday nap.
translation_text.mn95:5.2: He saw the brahmins and householders heading for the Godswood,
translation_text.mn95:5.4: “My butler, why are the brahmins and householders heading north for the Godswood?”
translation_text.mn95:6.1: “The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Opāsāda together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. He is staying in the Godswood to the north.
translation_text.mn95:6.3: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.mn95:6.4: They’re going to see that worthy Gotama.”
translation_text.mn95:6.5: “Well then, go to the brahmins and householders and say to them:
translation_text.mn95:6.7: you to wait, as he will also go to see the ascetic Gotama.’”
translation_text.mn95:6.8: “Yes, sir,” replied the butler, and did as he was asked.
translation_text.mn95:7.1: Now at that time around five hundred brahmins from abroad were residing in Opāsāda on some business.
translation_text.mn95:7.3: the brahmin Caṅkī was going to see the ascetic Gotama.
translation_text.mn95:7.4: They approached Caṅkī and said to him,
translation_text.mn95:7.5: “Is it really true that you are going to see the ascetic Gotama?”
translation_text.mn95:8.2: It’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;
translation_text.mn95:8.3: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.
translation_text.mn95:8.4: You are well born on both your mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.
translation_text.mn95:8.5: For this reason it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;
translation_text.mn95:8.6: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.
translation_text.mn95:8.8: You recite and remember the hymns, and have mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. You know them word-by-word, and their grammar. You are well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. …
translation_text.mn95:8.9: You are attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. You have divine looks and lustre, remarkable to behold. …
translation_text.mn95:8.10: You are ethical, mature in ethical conduct. …
translation_text.mn95:8.11: You’re a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning. …
translation_text.mn95:8.12: You teach the tutors of many, and teach three hundred young students to recite the hymns. …
translation_text.mn95:8.13: You’re honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by King Pasenadi of Kosala
translation_text.mn95:8.15: You live in Opāsāda, a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.
translation_text.mn95:8.16: For all these reasons it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;
translation_text.mn95:8.17: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.”
translation_text.mn95:9.1: When they had spoken, Caṅkī said to those brahmins:
translation_text.mn95:9.2: “Well then, gentlemen, listen to why it’s appropriate for me to go to see the ascetic Gotama,
translation_text.mn95:9.3: and it’s not appropriate for him to come to see me.
translation_text.mn95:9.4: He is well born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.
translation_text.mn95:9.5: For this reason it’s not appropriate for the ascetic Gotama to come to see me;
translation_text.mn95:9.6: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.
translation_text.mn95:9.7: When he went forth he abandoned abundant gold, both coined and uncoined, stored above and below ground. …
translation_text.mn95:9.8: He went forth from the lay life to homelessness while still a youth, young, with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life. …
translation_text.mn95:9.9: Though his mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces, he shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness. …
translation_text.mn95:9.10: He is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. He has divine looks and lustre, remarkable to behold. …
translation_text.mn95:9.11: He is ethical, possessing ethical conduct that is noble and skillful. …
translation_text.mn95:9.12: He’s a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning. …
translation_text.mn95:9.14: He has ended sensual desire, and is rid of caprice. …
translation_text.mn95:9.15: He teaches the efficacy of deeds and action. He doesn’t wish any harm upon the community of brahmins. …
translation_text.mn95:9.16: He went forth from an eminent family of unbroken aristocratic lineage. …
translation_text.mn95:9.17: He went forth from a rich, affluent, and wealthy family. …
translation_text.mn95:9.18: People come from distant lands and distant countries to question him. …
translation_text.mn95:9.19: Many thousands of deities have gone for refuge for life to him. …
translation_text.mn95:9.21: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’ …
translation_text.mn95:9.22: He has the thirty-two marks of a great man. …
translation_text.mn95:9.23: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …
translation_text.mn95:9.24: King Pasenadi of Kosala and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …
translation_text.mn95:9.25: The brahmin Pokkharasāti and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …
translation_text.mn95:9.26: The ascetic Gotama has arrived to stay in the Godswood to the north of Opāsāda.
translation_text.mn95:9.27: Any ascetic or brahmin who comes to stay in our village district is our guest,
translation_text.mn95:9.28: and should be honored and respected as such.
translation_text.mn95:9.31: For this reason, too, it’s not appropriate for the worthy Gotama to come to see me,
translation_text.mn95:9.32: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.
translation_text.mn95:9.33: This is the extent of the worthy Gotama’s praise that I have memorized. But his praises are not confined to this,
translation_text.mn95:9.34: for the praise of the worthy Gotama is limitless.
translation_text.mn95:9.35: The possession of even a single one of these factors makes it inappropriate for the worthy Gotama to come to see me,
translation_text.mn95:9.36: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.
translation_text.mn95:9.37: Well then, gentlemen, let’s all go to see the ascetic Gotama.”
translation_text.mn95:10.1: Then Caṅkī together with a large group of brahmins went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn95:10.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
translation_text.mn95:11.1: Now at that time the Buddha was sitting engaged in some polite conversation together with some very senior brahmins.
translation_text.mn95:11.2: And the student Kāpaṭika was sitting in that assembly. He was young, tonsured, and sixteen years old. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. He knew them word-by-word, and their grammar. He was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.
translation_text.mn95:11.3: While the senior brahmins were conversing together with the Buddha, he interrupted.
translation_text.mn95:11.5: “Venerable Bhāradvāja, don’t interrupt the senior brahmins.
translation_text.mn95:11.7: When he had spoken, Caṅkī said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn95:11.8: “Worthy Gotama, don’t rebuke the student Kāpaṭika.
translation_text.mn95:11.9: He’s a gentleman, learned and astute, who enunciates well. He is capable of debating with the worthy Gotama about this.”
translation_text.mn95:12.1: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn95:12.2: “Clearly the student Kāpaṭika will talk about the scriptural heritage of the three Vedas.
translation_text.mn95:12.3: That’s why the brahmins put him at the front.”
translation_text.mn95:12.5: “When the ascetic Gotama looks at me, I’ll ask him a question.”
translation_text.mn95:12.6: Then the Buddha, knowing Kāpaṭika’s train of thought, looked at him.
translation_text.mn95:12.8: “The ascetic Gotama is engaging with me.
translation_text.mn95:12.9: Why don’t I ask him a question?”
translation_text.mn95:12.11: “Worthy Gotama, regarding that which by the lineage of testament and by canonical authority is the ancient hymnal of the brahmins, the brahmins come to the categorical conclusion:
translation_text.mn95:12.12: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.mn95:12.13: What do you say about this?”
translation_text.mn95:13.1: “Well, Bhāradvāja, is there even a single one of the brahmins who says this:
translation_text.mn95:13.3: this is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
translation_text.mn95:13.5: “Well, is there even a single tutor of the brahmins, or a tutors’ tutor, or anyone back to the seventh generation of tutors, who says this:
translation_text.mn95:13.7: this is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
translation_text.mn95:13.9: “Well, what of the ancient seers of the brahmins, namely Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu? They were the authors and propagators of the hymns. Their hymnal was sung and propagated and compiled in ancient times; and these days, brahmins continue to sing and chant it, chanting what was chanted and teaching what was taught.
translation_text.mn95:13.12: this is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
translation_text.mn95:13.14: “So, Bhāradvāja, it seems that there is not a single one of the brahmins,
translation_text.mn95:13.17: not even anyone back to the seventh generation of tutors,
translation_text.mn95:13.20: nor even the ancient seers of the brahmins who say:
translation_text.mn95:13.22: this is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.mn95:13.23: Suppose there was a queue of blind men, each holding the one in front: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.
translation_text.mn95:13.24: In the same way, it seems to me that the brahmins’ statement turns out to be like a queue of blind men: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.
translation_text.mn95:13.26: This being so, doesn’t the brahmins’ faith turn out to be baseless?”
translation_text.mn95:14.1: “The brahmins don’t just honor this because of faith, but also because of oral transmission.”
translation_text.mn95:14.2: “First you relied on faith, now you speak of oral transmission.
translation_text.mn95:14.3: These five things can be seen to turn out in two different ways.
translation_text.mn95:14.5: Faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, and acceptance of a view after deliberation.
translation_text.mn95:14.7: Even though you have full faith in something, it may be vacuous, hollow, and false.
translation_text.mn95:14.8: And even if you don’t have full faith in something, it may be true and real, not otherwise.
translation_text.mn95:14.9: Even though you fully endorse something …
translation_text.mn95:14.11: something may be well thought out …
translation_text.mn95:14.12: something may be well deliberated, it may be vacuous, hollow, and false.
translation_text.mn95:14.13: And even if something is not well deliberated, it may be true and real, not otherwise.
translation_text.mn95:14.14: For a sensible person who is preserving truth this is not sufficient to come to the categorical conclusion:
translation_text.mn95:14.15: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’”
translation_text.mn95:15.1: “But worthy Gotama, how do you define the preservation of truth?”
translation_text.mn95:15.4: they preserve truth by saying, ‘Such is my faith.’
translation_text.mn95:15.5: But they don’t yet come to the categorical conclusion:
translation_text.mn95:15.6: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.mn95:15.7: If a person has a belief …
translation_text.mn95:15.8: or has received an oral transmission …
translation_text.mn95:15.9: or has a reasoned reflection about something …
translation_text.mn95:15.10: or has accepted a view after contemplation,
translation_text.mn95:15.11: they preserve truth by saying, ‘Such is the view I have accepted after contemplation.’
translation_text.mn95:15.12: But they don’t yet come to the categorical conclusion:
translation_text.mn95:15.13: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.mn95:15.14: That’s how the preservation of truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. I describe the preservation of truth as defined in this way.
translation_text.mn95:15.15: But this is not yet the awakening to the truth.”
translation_text.mn95:16.1: “That’s how the preservation of truth is defined, worthy Gotama. We regard the preservation of truth as defined in this way.
translation_text.mn95:16.2: But worthy Gotama, how do you define awakening to the truth?”
translation_text.mn95:17.1: “Bhāradvāja, take the case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.
translation_text.mn95:17.2: A householder or their child approaches and scrutinizes them for three kinds of things:
translation_text.mn95:17.3: things that arouse greed, things that provoke hate, and things that promote delusion.
translation_text.mn95:17.4: ‘Does this venerable have any qualities that arouse greed? Such qualities that, were their mind to be overwhelmed by them, they might say
translation_text.mn95:17.5: that they know, even though they don’t know, or that they see, even though they don’t see;
translation_text.mn95:17.6: or that they might encourage others to do what is for their lasting harm and suffering?’
translation_text.mn95:17.8: ‘This venerable has no such qualities that arouse greed.
translation_text.mn95:17.11: Rather, that venerable has bodily and verbal behavior like that of someone without greed.
translation_text.mn95:17.12: And the principle that they teach is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.
translation_text.mn95:17.13: It’s not easy for someone with greed to teach this.’
translation_text.mn95:18.1: Scrutinizing them in this way they see that they are purified of qualities that arouse greed. Next, they search them for qualities that provoke hate.
translation_text.mn95:18.2: ‘Does this venerable have any qualities that provoke hate? Such qualities that, were their mind to be overwhelmed by them, they might say
translation_text.mn95:18.3: that they know, even though they don’t know, or that they see, even though they don’t see;
translation_text.mn95:18.4: or that they might encourage others to do what is for their lasting harm and suffering?’
translation_text.mn95:18.6: ‘This venerable has no such qualities that provoke hate.
translation_text.mn95:18.9: Rather, that venerable has bodily and verbal behavior like that of someone without hate.
translation_text.mn95:18.10: And the principle that they teach is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.
translation_text.mn95:18.11: It’s not easy for someone with hate to teach this.’
translation_text.mn95:19.1: Scrutinizing them in this way they see that they are purified of qualities that provoke hate. Next, they scrutinize them for qualities that promote delusion.
translation_text.mn95:19.2: ‘Does this venerable have any qualities that promote delusion? Such qualities that, were their mind to be overwhelmed by them, they might say
translation_text.mn95:19.3: that they know, even though they don’t know, or that they see, even though they don’t see;
translation_text.mn95:19.4: or that they might encourage others to do what is for their lasting harm and suffering?’
translation_text.mn95:19.6: ‘This venerable has no such qualities that promote delusion.
translation_text.mn95:19.9: Rather, that venerable has bodily and verbal behavior like that of someone without delusion.
translation_text.mn95:19.10: And the principle that they teach is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.
translation_text.mn95:19.11: It’s not easy for someone with delusion to teach this.’
translation_text.mn95:20.1: Scrutinizing them in this way they see that they are purified of qualities that promote delusion.
translation_text.mn95:20.2: Next, they place faith in them. When faith has arisen they approach the teacher. They pay homage, actively listen, hear the teachings, remember the teachings, examine their meaning, and accept them after deliberation. Then enthusiasm springs up; they apply zeal, weigh up, and strive. Striving, they directly realize the ultimate truth, and see it with penetrating wisdom.
translation_text.mn95:20.3: That’s how the awakening to truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. I describe the awakening to truth as defined in this way.
translation_text.mn95:20.4: But this is not yet the attainment of truth.”
translation_text.mn95:21.1: “That’s how the awakening to truth is defined, worthy Gotama. I regard the awakening to truth as defined in this way.
translation_text.mn95:21.2: But worthy Gotama, how do you define the attainment of truth?”
translation_text.mn95:21.4: “By the cultivation, development, and making much of these very same things there is the attainment of truth.
translation_text.mn95:21.5: That’s how the attainment of truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. I describe the attainment of truth as defined in this way.”
translation_text.mn95:22.1: “That’s how the attainment of truth is defined, worthy Gotama. I regard the attainment of truth as defined in this way.
translation_text.mn95:22.2: But what quality is helpful for arriving at the truth?”
translation_text.mn95:22.4: “Striving is helpful for arriving at the truth.
translation_text.mn95:22.5: If you don’t strive, you won’t arrive at the truth.
translation_text.mn95:22.6: You arrive at the truth because you strive.
translation_text.mn95:22.7: That’s why striving is helpful for arriving at the truth.”
translation_text.mn95:23.1: “But what quality is helpful for striving?”
translation_text.mn95:23.3: “Weighing up the teachings is helpful for striving …
translation_text.mn95:24.3: Zeal is helpful for weighing up the teachings …
translation_text.mn95:26.3: Acceptance of the teachings after deliberation is helpful for enthusiasm …
translation_text.mn95:27.3: Examining the meaning of the teachings is helpful for accepting them after deliberation …
translation_text.mn95:28.3: Remembering the teachings is helpful for examining their meaning …
translation_text.mn95:29.3: Hearing the teachings is helpful for remembering the teachings …
translation_text.mn95:30.3: Active listening is helpful for hearing the teachings …
translation_text.mn95:31.3: Paying homage is helpful for active listening …
translation_text.mn95:32.3: Approaching is helpful for paying homage …
translation_text.mn95:33.3: Faith is helpful for approaching a teacher.
translation_text.mn95:33.4: If you don’t give rise to faith, you won’t approach a teacher.
translation_text.mn95:33.5: You approach a teacher because you have faith.
translation_text.mn95:33.6: That’s why faith is helpful for approaching a teacher.”
translation_text.mn95:34.1: “I’ve asked the worthy Gotama about the preservation of truth, and he has answered me.
translation_text.mn95:34.2: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.
translation_text.mn95:34.3: I’ve asked the worthy Gotama about awakening to the truth, and he has answered me.
translation_text.mn95:34.4: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.
translation_text.mn95:34.5: I’ve asked the worthy Gotama about the attainment of truth, and he has answered me.
translation_text.mn95:34.6: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.
translation_text.mn95:34.7: I’ve asked the worthy Gotama about the things that are helpful for the attainment of truth, and he has answered me.
translation_text.mn95:34.8: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.
translation_text.mn95:34.9: Whatever I have asked the worthy Gotama about he has answered me.
translation_text.mn95:34.10: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.
translation_text.mn95:34.11: Worthy Gotama, I used to think this:
translation_text.mn95:34.12: ‘Who are these shavelings, fake ascetics, primitives, black spawn from the feet of our kinsman next to those who understand the teaching?’
translation_text.mn95:34.13: The Buddha has inspired me to have love, confidence, and respect for ascetics!
translation_text.mn95:35.2: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
